Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Hammerstein> @Zatoichi   My post was relevant to your description, it just required some thought  and further education on your end.  BTCP was a fork of ZCL.  In my opinion, ZCL was a copy and paste job  of Zcash by, and again in my opinion, some of the greatest scammers in crypto, eg Rhett Creighton and company (he copied Zcash in its entirety and removed a few line of codes, eg the founders fee, and used envy tactics to convince people that legitimate developed like Vitalik were scamming them with the fee to get victims do dump money into his project).  BTCP was a straight copy of ZCL without much further development in my opinion. There was potentially much more fraudulent activity with respect to BTCP, eg the code had an ‚Äúaccidental flaw‚Äù that resulted in ‚Äúsomeone‚Äù taking advantage of the premine and generating 2 million coins out of nowhere and cratering the price of BTCP.  On this front alone BTCH is superior to BTCP.  No such vulnerability exists in BTCH.

So when you reference technology in relation to BTCP and any coin with any legitimate development, eg BTCH, it sounds suspect to me and it sounds like you may not be aware what you are comparing it to.   BTCH may or may not be dead, but comparing it to something that has almost no technical development of any kind and was probably created with the pure and unadulterared intent to scam people, ie BTCP, is unfair and incomplete.

The net of it is that BTCH has several technical features that BTCP does not have, but that isn‚Äôt saying much.  You implied further development was required for it to catch up. There‚Äôs nothing to catch up to.

Of course, this post is my opinion and should not be interpreted as a statement of fact. If I am wrong on anything I am saying, those with more knowledge can correct me.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <ITM> @dukeleto Agree.  I use to be a huge supporter of Nodejs. Lately to get work done was a pain. So many library changes, messed up packages and versions. 
  I switch to C# Dotnet Core for all my programs.
I use QT and C++ alot for all the huge programs. 
I only use Nodejs adhoc tasks with pm2 manager and for Angular/React Development.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I inherited the hush-ng codebase which was nodeJS, but I am not a js coder nor do I think it's secure to write GUI wallets with nodejs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the nodejs ecosystem changes so fast, all the dependencies of hush-ng have incompat changes and CVEs and nothing works anymore

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> so it was a quite easy choice to abandon, it no longer works and would take immense energy to get back to working again, and I am 100% not interested in that. So the future for Hush is having Swing + QT based GUI wallets for the desktop
